author: Staff Reporter
title: Ferguson warns on union influence | Business Spectator
text:
Martin Ferguson, a former federal energy minister through the Rudd and Gillard governments, has hit out at union influence over the Labor party, claiming it is “getting out of control”, The Australian Financial Review reports.
Mr Ferguson, who is also a former ACTU president, slammed union criticism of the ALP’s support of Australia's trade agreement with China as well as its resistance to IR reform, claiming it was an ominous sign for the future of the party.
The former MP was, however, careful not to attack current leader Bill Shorten.
"I think Bill is trying to take the party forward in a very difficult environment. The influence of the unions has not occurred overnight since Bill took over. It's cemented in place over the last 10 to 15 years and I think it's getting out of control,” he told the AFR .
Mr Ferguson has not shied away from criticising the ALP since leaving office in 2013 and taking up a role as an advocate for the resources sector.
